awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Sustaining Moore's Law Through Introspective Computing: A Comprehensive System For Reliability and Energy Optimization in Modern Computing Devices
awd_abstract_narration:
Whether one is concerned about data-center carbon footprint or battery life of mobile devices, the microprocessor is a dominating consumer of energy.  Transistor technology scaling, whose rate is expressed by Moore?s Law, is a regular progression of transistor size reductions down to nanometer dimensions.  Historically, this scaling has led to significant improvements in performance and energy efficiency, but more recently scaling has created severe reliability challenges due to difficulties in building components at near-atomic scale.  To ensure correctness, chips are operated with static and worst-case safety margins that account for more than 70% of the total energy used by a CPU.  This research program specifically addresses that energy wastage by intelligently tightening safety margins and making them dynamic in order to ensure reliable operation with dramatic reductions in expended energy.  The success of this research effort will lead to substantial reduction in energy wasted by semiconductor devices for the purpose of improving battery life, environmental impact, and operating costs.  It will also encourage the use of continuous self-adjustment and adaptation across an array of computing technologies.

In addition to being dependent on the power supply voltage and device temperature, the power and switching delay of a transistor varies substantially with random dopant fluctuation and aging.  In current practice, the worst-case combination of factors that affect transistor power consumption and delay are used to size device geometries and define an operating voltage guard band.  This ensures reliable operation but leads to unnecessary energy wastage, as the worst-case combinations are unlikely to occur in reality.  In this work, machine learning is used to correlate environmental and controllable factors that affect circuit delay and power and dynamically predict the minimum safe guard band.  If error-resilient components are used, the guard band can be eliminated entirely.  To realize maximum benefit, the system design is optimized across the boundaries of circuit, architectural, and software layers.  Combining machine learning, proactive closed-loop control, and a cost/benefit-driven approach to actuator and on-chip sensor allocation, circuit designers and architects are provided with a comprehensive methodology for creating introspective computing devices that dramatically lower energy and adapt automatically to all environmental and workload conditions.

por.por_cntn:
The importance of efficiency and automation cannot be overstated in today's world, and engineers must optimize very complex mechanical and computing systems. Unofrutnately, many of these systems are highly nonlinear and suffer substantial control latency, making traditional control systems inadequate. We have addressed this problem by (a) applying machine learning to develop preductive models of nonlinear systems, (b) developing fast search algorithms for finding optimal control inputs, and (c) incorporating these into a control feedback loop that achieves highest efficiency or performance from the controlled system. We refer to our strategy as "Introspective Control," because it is intended to learn online to incrementally improve predictive accuracy, and it makes control decisions based on search through control options, making this much like an intelligent simulation-in-the-loop strategy.

In our AIAA 2019 paper (Miller, Zaichik), we applied this methodology to the hydraulic pistons used in a flight simulator at the NASA Langley Resaerch Center. It outperformed all other control strategies significantly, and it beat NASA's existing control algorithm by 5x in gain bandwidth and 2.3x in phase bandwidth. Moreover, transient response showed little to no overshoot while also improving rise and settling time. We also yielded insight into selecting fitness functions that affect overall closed loop performance.

The AIAA paper is just one example of the kind of system that Introspective Control can be applied to. The broad range of nonlinear systems that would benefit from this methodology include computing systems (circuit performance and reliablility, datacenter energy efficiency, etc.), many other types of mechanical systems (rocketry, public transport, vehicle stability control), manufacturing and automation (assembly lines, food production, etc.), and even human-oriented systems (hospital bed assignment and resource allocation, improving queue throughput for public transport and amusement parks, etc.).

When you are a child, your parents teach you to "think before you act." Introspective Control is the embodiment of this principle, and it should inspire other scientists and engineers to develop increasingly intelligent control systems, on the shoulders of today's advanced machine learning methodologies and AI search algorithms.
